row.name: cors_domains
row.inlineHelp: You can define domains or subdomains like http://example.com or http://stats.example.com. Or to allow cross domain requests for all domains simply add a *

row.title: Configuration for server variables used by GeoIP 2 server modules

row.name: geoip2usecustom
row.title: I use the Geoip2 server module (Nginx, Apache…) and want to configure server variables

row.name: enableBruteForceDetection
row.title: Enable Brute-force Detection
row.description: Logs out users making too many password guesses within a timeframe for a while. This prevents anyone from testing all combinations. Getting a shared IP blocked also locks out its other users.

row.name: maxAllowedRetries
row.title: Number of allowed login retries within a given time frame
row.description: Blocks the IP if more than this number of failed logins are recorded within the time frame set below.

row.name: allowedRetriesTimeRange
row.title: Count login retries within this time range in minutes
row.description: Enter a number of minutes.

row.name: blacklistedBruteForceIps
row.title: Always block these IPs from logging in
row.description: Enter one IP address or one IP range per line. You can use CIDR notation e.g: 1.2.3.4/24 or you can use wildcards, e.g: 1.2.3.* or 1.2.*.* If an IP is on both the list of IPs to block and never block, it is blocked.

row.name: whitelisteBruteForceIps
row.title: Never block these IPs from logging in
row.description: Enter one IP address or one IP range per line. You can use CIDR notation e.g: 1.2.3.4/24 or you can use wildcards, e.g: 1.2.3.* or 1.2.*.* If an IP is on both the list of IPs to block and never block, it is blocked.

row.name: enablePasswordStrengthCheck
row.title: Force strong passwords to be used
row.inlineHelp:
Forces users to create strong passwords by requiring them to meet a series of complex rules:
  • At least 12 characters
  • Contains a lowercase letter
  • Contains an uppercase letter
  • Contains a number
  • Contains a special character

row.name: twoFactorAuthRequired
row.title: Require two-factor authentication for everyone
row.description: Requires other users also log in with 2FA by using an OTP app on their mobile device. (As a prerequisite, you must use 2FA yourself.)

row.name: twoFactorAuthName
row.title: Two-factor authentication title
row.description: The name of the title to display that will be displayed in the Authenticator app.

row.name: allowedEmailDomains
row.title: Restrict login email domains
row.description: This feature restricts the email domains that can be used when inviting, adding or updating users. This is good for privacy protection as it can prevent data sharing with third parties. It can also improve security by preventing users from changing their email address to a personal email. Additionally, it can act as an extra layer of protection against security attacks. For example, accidental typos in the email address.
row.inlineHelp:
Currently, these email domains are in use and would need to be allowed:
example.org

row.name: enableInactiveUsersNotifications
row.title: Send monthly security email with list of inactive users
row.description: For security reasons, Matomo can notify all Superusers once a month with a list of accounts that haven’t logged in for more than 6 months. This helps you review and remove old user accounts that may no longer be needed.

row.name: release_channel
row.inlineHelp:
While our development process includes thousands of automated tests, Beta Testers play a key role in achieving the "No bug policy" in Matomo.
If Matomo is a critical part of your business, we recommend you use the latest stable release. If you use the latest beta and you find a bug or have a suggestion, please see here.
LTS (Long Term Support) versions receive only security and bug-fixes.

row.name: enable_plugin_update_communication
row.inlineHelp: An email will be sent to Super Users when there is a new version available for a plugin.
row.introduction: Send an email when a plugin update is available

row.name: disable_visitor_log
row.title: Turn off visits log and visitor profiles
row.inlineHelp: Also removes features that depend on these, like the e-commerce log, the segmented visits-log, the real-time map or the real-time widget. May be required to comply with local privacy laws/guidelines.

row.name: disable_visitor_profile
row.title: Turn off visitor profiles
row.inlineHelp: All visits-log related features always function.

row.name: ImprintUrl
row.title: Imprint URL
row.description: A link to your Imprint page. If you set this, it will be displayed at the bottom of the login page and on pages that the 'anonymous' user can access.

row.name: privacyPolicyUrl
row.title: Privacy Policy URL
row.description: A link to your Privacy Policy page. If you set this, it will be displayed at the bottom of the login page and on pages that the 'anonymous' user can access.

row.name: termsAndConditionUrl
row.title: Terms & Conditions URL
row.description: A link to your Terms & Conditions page. If you set this, it will be displayed at the bottom of the login page and on pages that the 'anonymous' user can access.

row.name: showInEmbeddedWidgets
row.title: Show in embedded widgets
row.description: If checked, a link to your Privacy Policy and your Terms & Conditions will be displayed at the bottom of embedded widgets.

row.name: metric
row.title: Metric to display
row.description: Choose the metric that should be displayed in the browser tab

row.name: browsers
row.title: Supported Browsers
row.description: The value will be only displayed in the following browsers

row.name: description
row.title: Description for value
row.value: This is the value: Another line
row.defaultValue: This is the value: Another line
row.description: This description will be displayed next to the value

row.name: password
row.title: API password
row.description: Password for the 3rd API where we fetch the value

row.name: restrictTagManagerAccess
row.title: Restrict access to Matomo Tag Manager

availableValues.view: Users with at least view permission
availableValues.write: Users with at least write permission
availableValues.admin: Users with at least admin permission
availableValues.superuser: Users with at least superuser permission

row.description: Define who can see the Matomo Tag Manager section. This can be helpful when you have many users with the View permission, or if your Tag Manager configuration is very complex.

row.name: restrictCustomTemplates
row.title: Restrict usage of custom templates

availableValues.admin: Users with at least admin permission can use them
availableValues.superuser: Only Super Users can use them

row.description: This setting defines who can use custom templates or whether they should be completely disabled. Changing this setting can improve the security on your website. When you configure a trigger, tag, or a variable, some of them may allow a Matomo user to enter HTML or JavaScript which will be executed on your website. Entering custom code cannot only break the container in case there is an error, but also allows them to execute any JavaScript code on your website. This can be misused to steal for example sensitive information on your website. If you do not want to allow your team members to enter any JavaScript code, you may want to disable this setting.

row.name: environments
row.title: Environments
row.description: Define one or multiple additional environments. Please note that if you remove any environment, generated container files that exist for a specific environment will be removed and will be no longer available.

row.name: canUserOptOut
row.title: Let users disable anonymous tracking
row.description: If enabled, logged in users can opt out in their plugin settings. Anonymous users cannot opt out.

row.name: ownPiwikSiteId
row.title: Site Id
row.description: If specified, anonymized usage data will be sent to the specified site in this Matomo. This lets you analyze how you and your colleagues are using Matomo.
row.introduction: Send usage data to this Matomo

row.name: customSiteUrl
row.title: Matomo Url
row.introduction: Send usage data to a custom Matomo

row.name: customSiteId
row.title: Site Id
row.description: If a URL and Site Id is specified, usage data will be sent to the custom Matomo instance.

row.name: backend
row.title: Backend
row.inlineHelp: Select the backend you want to use for this feature. If you do not have any experience with Redis or it is not available on your server, we recommend using Mysql.</br>

row.name: useWhatRedisBackendType
row.title: Redis type
row.inlineHelp: Select which type of redis to use. Make sure to update host and port if needed. Once you have selected and saved the change, you will be able to specify multiple hosts and ports using comma separated lists for "Sentinel" and "Cluster" type only.</br>

row.name: sentinelMasterName
row.title: Redis Sentinel Master name
row.inlineHelp: The sentinel master name only needs to be configured if Sentinel is enabled.</br>

row.name: usePasswordForSentinelInstances
row.title: Use password with Redis Sentinels
row.inlineHelp: Only relevant if Sentinel is enabled.</br></br>If enabled, the Redis password will also be used when authenticating with Sentinel instances to obtain the master connection information. Otherwise, the password is only used to authenticate with the Redis master.</br>

row.name: redisHost
row.title: Redis host or unix socket
row.inlineHelp: Remote host or unix socket of the Redis server. Max 500 characters are allowed.</br></br>If your host requires a TLS connection, you can prepend the TLS protocol to your host like: tls://example-host.com. If that does not work, make sure that certificates are configured correctly on your Matomo server.</br>

row.name: redisPort
row.title: Redis port
row.inlineHelp: Port the Redis server is running on. Value should be between 1 and 65535. Use 0 if you are using unix socket to connect to Redis server.</br>

row.name: redisDatabase
row.title: Redis database
row.inlineHelp: In case you are using Redis for caching make sure to use a different database.</br>

row.name: redisPassword
row.title: Redis password
row.inlineHelp: Password set on the Redis server, if any. Redis can be instructed to require a password before allowing clients to execute commands.</br>

row.name: queueEnabled
row.title: Queue enabled
row.inlineHelp: If enabled, all tracking requests will be written into a queue instead of the directly into the database. Requires a Redis server and phpredis PHP extension if using Redis as a backend.</br>

row.name: numQueueWorkers
row.title: Number of queue workers
row.inlineHelp: Number of allowed maximum queue workers. Accepts a number between 1 and 4096. Best practice is to set the number of CPUs you want to make available for queue processing. Be aware you need to make sure to start the workers manually. We recommend to not use 9-15 workers, rather use 8 or 16 as the queue might not be distributed evenly into different queues.</br>

row.name: numRequestsToProcess
row.title: Number of requests that are processed in one batch
row.inlineHelp: Defines how many requests will be picked out of the queue and processed at once. Enter a number which is >= 1.</br>

row.name: processDuringTrackingRequest
row.title: Process during tracking request
row.inlineHelp: If enabled, we will process all requests within a queue during a normal tracking request once there are enough requests in the queue. This will not slow down the tracking request. If disabled, you have to setup a cronjob that executes the ./console queuedtracking:process console command eg every minute to process the queue.

row.name: block_clouds
row.title: Block tracking requests from the cloud
row.description: Blocks tracking requests originating from cloud providers like AWS, Azure, Digital Ocean, Google Cloud and Oracle by fetching a list of their IP ranges. It should be safe to turn on if you are only tracking using the JavaScript tracker, as their tracking requests do not orginate from clouds, unless they use a VPN that routes data through cloud providers. The setting applies to all your sites.

row.name: block_headless
row.title: Block headless browsers
row.description: These are browsers without a user interface, mostly used for automation. It should be safe to turn this on if you only have regular websites or apps. It can block additional bots and spam requests that otherwise would not be detected.

row.name: blockServerSideLibraries
row.title: Block tracking requests from server-side libraries
row.inlineHelp:
Use this if only using JavaScript Tracker, as other traffic will be attacks or spam anyway. It blocks tracking requests from cURL, HTTP, Guzzle, and Postman.
Note: Do not use it if track data using a server-side SDK like the Matomo PHP tracking SDK, Java SDK, Python SDK, Android or iOS SDK, or other server-side programming languages.

row.name: max_actions_allowed
row.title: Max actions to record per visit
row.description: A default of "0" records all actions. Most sites usually have no more than 100 to 300. It might be safe to assume other activity is tracking spam, a bot or an attack. Matomo stops recording further actions and blocks their IP addresses for up to 24 hours to reduce server load and preserve data accuracy.

row.name: notification_email
row.title: Notification email
row.description: This e-mail address will be notified whenever an IP is banned for having too many actions. In the future further notification reasons might be added.

row.name: excluded_countries
row.title: Exclude Countries
row.description: Don't track visitors from these countries. Visitors outside your target area will likely be bots or spammers, or you can use it to avoid privacy laws in other jurisdictions.

row.name: included_countries
row.title: Only track visitors from these countries
row.description: This excludes all other countries. The "exclude countries" setting has more info.
